Multiple sources: The expert's verdict mentions that the claim was supported by multiple sources, including tweets from different users and a Facebook post. This indicates that the authenticity of the claim was verified by cross-referencing information from various sources.
Comparison with previous instances: The expert's verdict highlights that the same image of the graffiti was shared during elections in Bihar in October 2020. By comparing the claim with previous instances of the same image, the authenticity of the claim can be verified.
Testimony from a journalist: A Kolkata-based journalist, Mayukh Ranjan Ghosh, replied to one of the viral tweets claiming that the image was shot in Kolkata, not Tamil Nadu. His testimony provides additional information that helps verify the authenticity of the claim.
Visual evidence: The expert's verdict mentions that photographs of the Metro Channel Control Post and Hare Street Police Station, which are mentioned in relation to the graffiti, are available on Google Maps. Additionally, a different angle of the graffiti was found in a report published by Scroll. These visual pieces of evidence can be used to verify the authenticity of the claim.
